settings.description: Tell your brand's story through images.

settings.text:
Finding the perfect piece of jewelry can be a deeply personal journey, one that takes time and exploration to discover what truly resonates with your style. With a vast array of options, from delicate bracelets to bold necklaces, the world of jewelry offers endless possibilities for self-expression. 

But which jewelry trends are capturing hearts across the U.S.? And which states are the most diamond-obsessed? We’ve taken it upon ourselves to find out! 

To do this, we looked at search demand across a wide range of jewelry items—necklaces, bracelets, rings and earrings—to identify the most standout trends nationwide. Additionally, we examined diamond preferences, including popular cuts, colors, carat weights, and jewelry items across all 50 states to uncover which regions embrace these sparkling gems the most.

settings.description: Tell your brand's story through images.

settings.title: Pearl earrings: 726,000 annual Google searches
settings.content: While pearls have always been a timeless choice, this year, they’re experiencing a major resurgence, with search demand up 83% year on year. From making waves on the runways and adorning top models to seamlessly blending into everyday wear, pearl earrings are re-emerging as a must-have accessory and proving themselves to be the most popular earring trend of the year.

settings.title: Hoop earrings: 594,000 annual Google searches
settings.content: There's no denying that hoop earrings are a cult favorite, beloved by many fashion icons across generations, from Jennifer Lopez and Madonna to Bella Hadid and Hailey Bieber. The true beauty of hoops lies in their versatility—they pair effortlessly with casual weekend outfits, polished workwear, streetwear, and occasion dressing, making them all the more deserving of their place as one of the most popular earring trends of the year.

settings.title: Stud earrings: 594,000 annual Google searches
settings.content: Tied with hoops at 594,000 annual searches, stud earrings remain a top choice for their versatility and timeless appeal. However, in 2024, the focus is shifting toward statement studs, especially chunky gold designs. Inspired by the '80s and seen on runways and celebrities, these bold earrings are making a strong comeback, becoming the new go-to for adding a touch of glamour to everyday outfits.

settings.title: Ear cuffs: 486,000 annual Google searches
settings.content: Ranking fourth, ear cuffs generated 486,000 searches this year. These non-traditional earrings have grown in popularity due to their bold, edgy look, offering a way to accessorize without needing additional piercings.

settings.title: Huggie earrings: 325,200 annual Google searches
settings.content: Rounding out the top five are huggie earrings, with 325,200 annual Google searches and a notable 23% year-on-year increase in demand. Named for the way they "hug" the earlobe, huggie earrings have become a favorite among A-listers and have frequently  been spotted on red carpets throughout 2024 -  it's safe to say they aren't going anywhere anytime soon!

settings.title: Pearl necklaces: 1,320,000 annual Google searches
settings.content: Pearls are having a moment this year, not just in earrings but also in necklaces. With a staggering 1,320,000 annual searches and an 82% year-on-year increase, it’s clear that pearl jewelry is capturing the hearts of fashion enthusiasts across the U.S. and establishing itself as a must-have accessory in 2024.

settings.title: Initial necklaces: 888,000 annual Google searches
settings.content: With 888,000 annual searches and a 22% year-on-year increase, initial necklaces are more popular than ever. These personalized and giftable pieces add a distinctive touch to any outfit. Fashion enthusiasts are embracing them with unique letter charms and stylish monograms from renowned fashion houses, highlighting their trendsetting status in 2024.

settings.title: Birthstone necklaces: 486,000 annual Google searches
settings.content: Much like initials, birthstone necklaces are deeply personal—perhaps personalization is the defining theme for 2024? With 486,000 annual searches and a 23% year-on-year increase, birthstone necklaces are growing in popularity. These accessories offer a unique way to express individuality and celebrate personal milestones.

settings.title: Tennis necklaces: 486,000 annual Google searches
settings.content: Often seen as the younger sibling of the tennis bracelet, tennis necklaces are being embraced by a new generation of style icons, including Zendaya and Emily Ratajkowski. This surge in popularity is largely attributed to the appeal of lab-grown diamonds, positioning tennis necklaces as both a stylish and sustainable trend for 2024.

settings.title: Locket necklaces: 397,200 annual Google searches
settings.content: Locket necklaces are making a comeback, with interest up 22% year on year. As personalized jewelry continues to dominate trends, these timeless pieces offer both sentiment and fashion, allowing wearers to keep personal photos or momentos close while adding a touch of nostalgia to any outfit.

settings.title: Tennis bracelets: 1,980,000 annual Google searches
settings.content: The Zendaya Effect plays a significant role in this trend. Her stunning jewelry selections, along with the success of the film Challengers, have helped to maintain the high demand for tennis bracelets and necklaces throughout 2024 and likely into 2025. Interest is up 23% year on year, and it’s not just Zendaya fueling the trend—celebrities like Sofia Richie Grainge, Taylor Swift, and Nicola Peltz-Beckham have been spotted wearing them, adding to the growing appeal of this effortlessly chic, timeless piece.

settings.title: Charm bracelets: 1,320,000 annual Google searches
settings.content: Charm bracelets are back in style, generating 1.32 million annual searches. Once a staple for DIY lovers in the ’90s and Noughties, they now allow wearers to showcase their personalities through curated charms, blending nostalgia with modern style.

settings.title: Friendship bracelets: 1,086,000 annual Google searches
settings.content: Taylor Swift, and her army of Swifties, have single handedly revitalized the friendship bracelet trend during the Eras Tour, helping to generate over 1.08 million annual searches. These colorful accessories promote personal expression and connection, making them a fresh take on a cherished childhood favorite.

settings.title: Bangles: 594,000 annual Google searches
settings.content: Bangles are experiencing a resurgence, with 594,000 annual Google searches. Chunky designs that nod to the bold styles of the '70s and '80s are particularly popular this year.. This season, oversized cuffs and layered bangles have taken center stage in fashion collections, showcasing their versatility and bold statement potential.

settings.title: Beaded bracelets: 594,000 annual Google searches
settings.content: Much like friendship bracelets, beaded bracelets share a similar playful aesthetic and are making a comeback this year with 594,000 annual searches. This trend promotes personal expression, enabling wearers to mix and match vibrant beads for a unique and colorful accessory.

settings.title: Birthstone rings: 726,000 annual Google searches
settings.content: Topping the list, birthstone rings are riding high on the trend wave, up 646% year on year. This again, reflects the growing trend for personalized jewelry, as people seek meaningful, custom pieces. Stackable designs, minimalist settings, and mixed metals are particularly popular trends within the birthstone category.

settings.title: Signet rings: 594,000 annual Google searches
settings.content: With 594,000 annual searches, signet rings are enjoying a revival as symbols of personal identity and tradition. Popular trends include minimalist styles and gemstone accents, making signet rings a versatile choice for modern wearers.

settings.title: Stackable rings: 325,200 annual Google searches
settings.content: With 325,200 annual searches, stackable rings are one of the hottest trends of 2024, embraced by celebrities and fashion influencers alike. This trend allows wearers to personalize their jewelry, mixing and matching different styles, metals, and textures to express their individuality.

settings.title: Pinky rings: 266,400 annual Google searches
settings.content: In fourth place, pinky rings are making a statement with 266,400 annual searches, reflecting a 50% increase year-on-year. Once considered a quirky accessory, pinky rings are now embraced as a bold fashion choice, appealing to both men and women who want to add a touch of flair to their look.

settings.title: Cluster rings: 177,600 annual Google searches
settings.content: Fifth place goes to cluster rings, which have also seen a 50% year-on-year rise, totaling 177,600 annual searches. These rings, featuring multiple stones grouped together, are favored for their unique and eye-catching designs. Cluster rings allow for creative expression, as they can showcase a variety of gemstones and styles, making them perfect for those who love to stand out.

settings.text: To uncover the most diamond-obsessed regions in the U.S., we dived into search data that showcases preferences for different cuts, colors, carat weights, and jewelry styles. Join us as we reveal which regions sparkle the brightest when it comes to their love for all things diamond!

1. West

The West is the most diamond-obsessed region in the U.S., with over 3 million annual searches for diamond-related terms. Despite having fewer states than other regions, it tops the list, largely thanks to Utah, which ranks as the most diamond-obsessed state in the country. The region also has a distinct fascination with black diamonds, with 544,440 annual searches.

2. Northeast

Despite being the smallest region, the Northeast comes in second, generating 2.3 million searches for diamond-related terms each year. New York, home to the famous Diamond District, leads the region’s obsession with diamonds. The area attracts buyers and sellers from around the world, making New York a natural epicenter for diamond interest. It's no surprise that this iconic hub keeps the Northeast near the top of the list.

3. South

Coming in third, the South sees a significant number of searches, largely fueled by Texas, where residents account for 1.26 million diamond-related inquiries each year. Texas is particularly interested in diamond rings and earrings, reflecting the region’s love for bold, statement and luxury jewelry. As one of the largest states by population, Texas plays a major role in pushing the South’s diamond fascination to new heights.

4. Midwest

Despite ranking last, the Midwest still shows a strong interest in diamonds, with 2,258,880 Google searches for diamond-related terms. Larger states like Illinois, Michigan, and Ohio, drive much of this demand, with a particular interest in diamond jewelry like rings, necklaces, and bracelets.

custom_css: @media screen and (min-width: 750px) {.index-rte.section-padding .hero__content.hero__content--compact .hero__rte p:last-child {font-size: 19px; text-align: left; text-transform: none; }}

settings.title: The Most Popular Diamond Cuts in the US

settings.text:
1.Princess cut

Ranking first with 266,400 annual searches, the princess cut is known for its sharp and square shape. This contemporary style emerged in the late 20th century and has quickly become a favorite for its versatility and modern aesthetic. 

2.Emerald cut

Tying for first place with 266,400 annual searches, the emerald cut is known for its sleek, step-cut facets that create a striking "hall of mirrors" effect. Favored by icons like Beyoncé and Amal Clooney, its elongated shape not only makes fingers appear more slender in rings but also brings a refined edge to earrings and necklaces. This versatile cut adds understated elegance to various types of jewelry, making it a popular choice among jewelry lovers.

3.Radiant cut

With 97,200 searches, the radiant cut takes the third spot. This cut combines the brilliance of round diamonds with a square or rectangular shape, offering both sparkle and structure, making it a versatile option for those wanting a bit of both. It has gained popularity for its versatility, with celebrities like Jennifer Lawrence and Brittany Matthews opting for this striking cut.

4.Cushion cut

In fourth place, the cushion cut sees 79,200 annual searches. Often described as a blend of a square shape with rounded corners, it combines vintage charm with modern cutting techniques. Its soft, pillow-like silhouette appeals to people seeking a romantic yet unique look. Notable fans include Kim Kardashian and Meghan Markle, who both appreciate its timeless elegance.

5.Asscher cut

With 79,200 searches, the Asscher cut, which originated in the early 20th century, is a square variation of the emerald cut. It has seen a 22% increase in interest and is often chosen for its dramatic look, with celebrities appreciating its distinctiveness and heritage.

custom_css: @media screen and (min-width: 750px) {.index-rte.section-padding .hero__content.hero__content--compact .hero__rte p:last-child {font-size: 19px; text-align: left; text-transform: none; }}

settings.title: The Most Popular Diamond Colors in the US

settings.text:
1.Black diamond

With 1,620,000 annual searches, black diamonds lead the pack, accounting for over 40% of total color-related searches. Their bold, mysterious appeal makes them particularly popular in the West, with Utah, Colorado, and Wyoming taking the top spots for interest in this striking gem.

2.Blue diamond

The second most sought-after color, blue diamonds have 888,000 annual searches. Their captivating hue draws attention, especially in states like Nevada, California, and Oregon, where they are highly coveted for their rarity and unique beauty.

3.Pink diamond

With 397,200 searches, pink diamonds are predominantly searched in New York, where their romantic and luxurious qualities resonate strongly with consumers. This color’s allure is often associated with love and elegance.

4.Red diamond

Garnering 266,400 searches, red diamonds are rare and highly desired, with Alabama leading the search interest. Their striking color symbolizes passion and power, appealing to those looking for a truly unique gemstone.

5.Yellow diamond

Also with 266,400 annual searches, yellow diamonds are popular in Oregon, New York, and Florida. Known for their cheerful and vibrant appearance, these stones bring a sunny touch to jewelry, attracting a diverse audience across various regions.

custom_css: @media screen and (min-width: 750px) {.index-rte.section-padding .hero__content.hero__content--compact .hero__rte p:last-child {font-size: 19px; text-align: left; text-transform: none; }}

settings.title: The Most Popular Diamond Jewelry Items in the US

settings.text:
1.Diamond rings

With 1,320,000 annual searches, diamond rings are a top pick for jewelry lovers, especially in New York, where the state alone contributes 118,800 searches. Interest peaks every December, likely thanks to holiday proposals and the gift-giving spirit. Meanwhile, searches dip during the summer and early fall, showcasing the seasonal trends in diamond ring popularity.

2.Diamond earrings

Diamond earrings share the top spot, with 1,320,000 annual searches and a staggering 82% year-on-year increase. Illinois is at the forefront of this demand, accounting for 64,800 of these searches. Stars like Sydney Sweeney have been spotted in stunning diamond earrings that elevate their red-carpet looks, showcasing the versatility and elegance of this jewelry staple.

3.Diamond necklaces

With 888,000 searches per year, diamond necklaces are seeing a similar 82% boost. New York continues to lead the chart, with 79,200 searches, reinforcing its reputation as a key hub for diamond enthusiasts who covet elegant and statement-worthy pieces.

4.Diamond bracelets

Searched 397,200 times a year, diamond bracelets maintain a steady following, especially in New York, where the love for all things diamond truly shines. The ongoing demand for bracelets adds yet another layer to the state’s dominant role in the diamond market.

5.Diamond pendants

Trending upward, diamond pendants attract 177,600 searches annually. Big states like New York, Illinois, and Massachusetts contribute to this growing interest, proving that pendants remain a classic choice, favored for their elegance and versatility. They have been a popular choice on the red carpet as well, with celebs like Kaia Gerber showcasing exquisite diamond pendants that effortlessly complement their looks.

custom_css: @media screen and (min-width: 750px) {.index-rte.section-padding .hero__content.hero__content--compact .hero__rte p:last-child {font-size: 19px; text-align: left; text-transform: none; }}

settings.title: The Most Popular Diamond Size in the US

settings.text:
1. 3 Carat Diamond

Leading with 217,200 searches, the 3 carat diamond draws significant interest, particularly in Massachusetts, New York, and California. Although not the usual gemstone size found in jewelry, its popularity reflects the growing desire for eye-catching, statement pieces. 

2. 1 Carat Diamond

As the most common and affordable carat option it is no surprise that 1 carat diamonds get 177,600 searches annually. New York drives the demand for this classic choice, favored for its balance between size and cost.

3. 2 Carat Diamond

With 118,800 annual searches, 2 carat diamonds offer a bit more impact while still staying practical for many buyers.

4. 2.5 Carat Diamond

Pulling in 97,200 searches per year, 2.5 carat diamonds appeal to those looking for more presence without going too extravagant.

5. 5 Carat Diamond

Known for making a statement, 5 carat diamonds attract 79,200 searches annually. Washington leads the interest in this category, showing a love for larger, more luxurious stones.

The South sees a significant number of searches, largely fueled by Texas, where residents account for 1.26 million diamond-related inquiries each year. Texas is particularly interested in diamond rings and earrings, reflecting the region’s love for bold and statement jewelry. One of the largest states by population, plays a major role in pushing the South’s diamond fascination to new heights.

Despite ranking last, the Midwest still shows a strong interest in diamonds, with 2,258,880 Google searches for diamond-related terms. Larger states like Illinois, Michigan, and Ohio, drive much of this demand, with a particular interest in diamond jewelry like rings, necklaces, and bracelets.

Ranking first with 266,400 annual searches, the princess cut is known for its sharp and square shape. This contemporary style emerged in the late 20th century and has quickly become a favorite for its versatility and modern aesthetic.

The emerald cut, tying for first place with 266,400 annual searches, is known for its sleek step-cut facets that create a stunning "hall of mirrors" effect. It has gained popularity for its versatility, with celebrities like Jennifer Lawrence and Brittany Matthews opting for this striking cut.

In fourth place, the cushion cut sees 79,200 annual searches. Often described as a blend of a square shape with rounded corners, it combines vintage charm with modern cutting techniques. With 79,200 searches, the Asscher cut, which originated in the early 20th century, is a square variation of the emerald cut. It has seen a 22% increase in interest and is often chosen for its dramatic look, with celebrities appreciating its distinctiveness and heritage.

settings.text: To identify the biggest jewelry trends across the U.S., we analyzed search data for over 100 jewelry items categorized into four types: necklaces, bracelets, rings, and earrings. We ranked these items based on their popularity and examined trends to see which had increased over the past year. Focusing specifically on diamonds, we evaluated search data for the most sought-after cuts, colors, carat weights, and jewelry styles across all U.S. states and regions. To ensure our findings accurately reflected interest without being skewed by larger states like New York and Massachusetts, we adjusted search demand according to each state’s population. This approach allowed us to create a final ranking of the most diamond-obsessed states and regions.
